results.title: Not by choice
results.creator_credit: Max Lemon, Douglas White and Double Crown
results.brief_description: A glimpse of Sydney’s soup-kitchens and the down-and-outs for whom they provide meals. This documentary film gives a glimpse of the institutions and of the lives of the men they assist. Its frankly emotional approach avoids any attempt to explain causes or to offer solutions. In fact it suggests that strong personal pride is characteristic of these men, and would prohibit any easy solution.

results.title: Keith's story
results.brief_description: Although now struggling with Alzheimer’s disease, the stories of Keith’s achievements and adventures as told by his wife are a tribute to his inspirational life. Created as part of ‘Memory’s Voice: Capturing Stories of Courage’ in association with Vic Health and the Alzheimer’s Association.

results.title: Valley of the Yarra
results.creator_credit: Peter McEwan, Donald Pollock, Matthias Faubel and Victorian Town and Country Planning Board
results.brief_description: Using archival stills and prints, and aerial shots the film traces the Yarra River from its source in the Great Dividing Range to its entry into Port Phillip Bay, emphasising its importance as a natural asset. Also shows geographical features such as the delta from Princes Bridge, Melbourne to Fisherman’s Bend, the port complex and various sporting facilities. Discusses the planning policy for the Yarra Valley prepared by the Town and Country Planning Board, Victoria’s state planning authority. “Modern man causes problems to this priceless asset” (Liberal Minister Dick Hamer).
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter McEwan, Donald Pollock, Matthias Faubel and Victorian Town and Country Planning Board

results.title: Dur-e Dara
results.creator_credit: ACMI, Lisetta Moscardo and Helen Simondson
results.brief_description: Dur-e Dara has a long and accomplished career in the food industry and is the first woman President of the Restaurant and Caterers Association of Victoria. Dara is Convenor of the Victorian Women’s Trust; Vice-President of Philanthropy Australia; and board member of the Victorian Wineries Tourism Council and Business Matrix Victoria. She is Director of the Melbourne International Chamber Music Competition, and serves on the advisory boards of the Women’s Reference Group of the Victorian Equal Opportunity Commission; William Angliss College; RMIT School of Tourism and Hospitality; and the Swinburne School of Hospitality and Tourism.

results.title: Bushland fantasy
results.creator_credit: Soundmasters and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Provides glimpses of the many wild flowers and animals found in the Australian bush. Includes photographs of native flora, and animal life such as kangaroos, wallabies, platypus, lyrebirds and koalas. Many of these can be found in the wildlife sanctuary at Healesville where special efforts are made to arrange a proper diet for these animals. Narrated by John Dudley.

results.title: A young girls journey to the other side of the world
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Maria Sourtzis
results.brief_description: This is a story of migration through the eyes of a young girl. Maria recounts the long journey by boat, the memories of Bonegilla migrant reception centre and her early life in Melbourne.

results.title: Days of Echuca
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Barbara Day
results.brief_description: Barbara courageously and openly speaks of the hardships she has endured in her life and how she has managed to recover from the tragedies of her life because she draws support from her spirituality, her family and her community. This story was produced as part of a project called Voices from the Riverlands, in partnership with the Njernda Aboriginal Corporation.

results.title: [Ned Kelly cummerbund interview]
results.brief_description:
This collection of films has been generously donated by the Benalla Historical Society. The collection features moments in Benalla’s history and surrounding areas, including visits by the Governor of Victoria Sir Rohan Delacombe, ceremonies revealing various commemorative plaques, and the return of Ned Kelly’s cummerbund, thought to have been lost.

This film shows an interview with a member of the Benalla Historical Society, regarding a green, bloodstained sash or cummerbund worn by Ned Kelly at the Glenrowan siege. The sash was given to Ned at the age of ten by a family whose child Ned saved from drowning. Ned was wearing it at the Glenrowan siege when he was captured in 1880. A doctor who tended to his wounds took it off while Ned was unconscious and kept it. The family later donated the sash in 1973 to the Benalla Historical Society. It is now on display in the Benalla Costume and Kelly Museum.
